content.body: OMG, home internet is finally back.  This is the first time I've connected through my home router in very nearly exactly 14 days.
(It would be exactly 14 days in about 20 minutes.)
precision, we has it
i just noticed i have an issue using Image()
seems my js moves on before the image() data is ready
is there a solution for that?. i didnt notice it because the images were getting cached :/
having child point to parent assures treeness
ARIA does it the other way, whyc seems bad
(aria-owns)
s/whyc/which/
how can i embed base64 and make an image out of it for canvas?
drunknbass: data URL
now image.src?
not*
drunknbass: you can load the data: URL into image.src
any links?
everything i find doesnt work
and seems to be from b4 canvas
just http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2397.txt
ok how do i use this with image or drawImage?
notes "URL" in the title of that RFC
drunknbass: by using it as the URL of a new Image()
heh thx
i dunno why it wasnt working b4 but i changed single quotes to double and it works
lol
ahh it doesnt make a difference lol.. pre still wont show my images
drunknbass: does Pre support data URLs?
haha i didnt look
drunknbass: does it pass Acid2?
i have a problem with my js running b4 my image is loaded
thought it could have only limited support like IE8
and even trying to use the onload for the image didnt help
i guess ill sort it out later..
drunknbass: does what I said work for you in Firefox/Opera/Safari/Chrome, though?
yup
i actually had that before without the header
ok. good
when i added the header it gave me ilgal char errors but it was because i was using single quotes around the string
so after i changed to regular quotes and left the header in, it worked
but images still dont work on pre which was what i was trying to fix
i think i read something about the images needing to be loaded locally or something.. like from within the app bundle..
i also get my context sizes displaying wrong in webos so i think the pre webkit is just really messed up
wakes up , finds he has 99 new messages filtered to es-discuss, sighs
(That is less than 99 messages total because I get all the IDL mesages twice but the filters aren't bright enough to sort one copy to es-discuss and one copy to public-html)
drunknbass: Use image.onload to run some code once the image has loaded, or check image.complete to see if it's loaded yet, perhaps
oh i didnt know about complete
thx
Has reCAPTCHA recently become awful?
I seem to get <50% success rate, despite being certain I'm entering the words correctly
and I don't remember that much of a problem in the past
it's what happens when Google buys things
Oh, Google bought reCAPTCHA?
never heard about that
I'll blame Google, then
I've got a question about Web Workers - is this the right place to ask?
remysharp: It's as good a place as any
is there a way/flag to tell if a worker has been terminated?
I can see the "closed" flag being referenced in the spec
but I can't tell if it's new since FF + Safari have implemented workers
i.e. I've dumped a worker variable out to Firebug and I can't see any state flags or any way to tell
(Unrelated to workers) is the "Loop:" label in the "A start tag whose tag name is "li"" section of the "in body" phase of parsing on the wrong step?
Otherwise why do you keep looking for a node but never do anything with it
(I guess it should match the "dt" + etc. case below
Hi
I created a very simple page with HTML5 Doctype, to try embeded SVG, but it doesn't seem to work (in FF3.5 and Safari 4, both on Mac)
http://pastebin.com/d709d385f
Someone can explain me how to embed SVG in my HTML5 page plz ?
Everything i try doesnt work :/
Sephi-Chan: You need a nightly build of Firefox, and you need to enable the html5 parser in it.
Oh :(
So bad, i believed it was more accessible
the status of SVG in HTML5 is pretty fuzzy to me, isn't it in flux?
my impression is that the battle isn't over, you might get a different answer here tho
It will be, eventually, just need to wait for the browsers to be updated to support it.
isn't it still an ISSUE?
Do you have an idea of the time for it to be available in Safari/Firefox ? Is this time in days ? weaks ? or months ? :x
masinter: I dunno, not really paying that much attention to it.
i'm working on a webgame and i currently create a SVG map (using Raphael, to provide content for IE) and i ask for myself if using edge stuff like HTML5 is a good choice
sephi-chan: you know what they say about the Opera
sephi-chan: lots of people run IE6, and can't upgrade. do you want your game to work for them?
I don't really care about IE6 and IE in general
If i can support them, it's a plus
Sephi-Chan: No clue when Mozilla and Apple will enable SVG-in-html5 by default.
As for using html5... well, some of it is easily usable now (eg most new elements) or can be emulated using scripts. Some of it (eg svg-in-html5) will have to wait for newer browser versions.
well, wasn't the google chrome supposed to make HTML5 available for IE users? not sure if that applies to IE6 though
finds http://www.mozilla.org/projects/svg/
"SVG support is now included in the latest version of Mozilla Firefox! "
Uh :o
use the net, duke
There's a difference between supporting SVG and supporting SVG markup in html5 documents :p
what?
Try to use embed svg in HTML (event with HTML5 doctype) and you will see that it's not supported
I don't get it, HTML5 is backward compatible! how can there be things that work now that will break when moving to HTML5?
Uh ? How do you embed SVG now ?
Everyone (except IE) supports SVG using
The only change in HTML5 is that the text/html parser supports SVG elements
(which is only implemented in experimental Firefoxes)
You can always use proper XHTML, or create the SVG elements through the DOM (createElement etc)
which will work in every browser
(except IE obviously)
or use <object> as da3d says
(I think most browsers don't support SVG in - maybe only Opera?)
Doesn't Webkit support svg in , or am I misremembering?
Uhuh
finds http://www.spartanicus.utvinternet.ie/embed.htm#svg
I know it supports stuff like PDF in , but I'm not sure about SVG
pdf in img doesn't sound right
http://support.apple.com/kb/TA25197 says "Adds support for SVG images in elements and CSS images"
http://philip.html5.org/demos/canvas/svg/scale.html
Top-left is an SVG in
Seems to work in Opera (10) and Chromium (don't have Safari easily available)
Doesn't work in Firefox
With Safari 4/Mac
(Top-right image is the SVG scaled onto a <canvas> - Opera seems to do bitmap scaling, Chromium does vector scaling)
i see a page with a bend corner and fiew code
with the SVG logo
Yeah. SVG in text/html is currently rather experimental. If you need HTML with inline SVG markup you have to use XHTML until HTML5 parsers are widely deployed
(or use SVG as the root element and put XHTML in foreignContent I guess)
So in summary: sorry :(
Hmm
In my case, SVG is used to draw a map (like in the board game Risk)
My backend is made with Ruby on Rails, maybe i can use it to serve SVG
With its nice RESTful API, maybe i can do example.com/maps/1.svg
I think it's okay to use the SVG in a object with the good type
No ?
It is wuite possible that you don't need the SVG to be inline
If you cn put it in an external file and then load that somehow everything will be hunky-dory
hunky-dory ? I don't understand that :x (french inside)
Using SVG with <object> seems to be the most compatible, since it's supported everywhere except IE.
And for IE ? What is the best way ?
Chrome Frame or some SVG plugin (dunno how well those work or how many there are though), I suppose?
is excited!
I just came up with a brilliant and most simple solution to the issues with Selectors API
goes to spec it...
talk about a cliff hanger
I want it to be a surprise. :-)
most likely I'll forget and never know
I just came up with a brilliant and most simple solution to world peace!
I'll write it down somewhere in a while
haha
JohnResig, yt?
Lachy, just don't do a Fermat
what's a Fermat?
faceplams
Fermat was a mathematician
Lachy: Go learn your mathematicians!
who wrote in the sidebar of his noteback that some property of maths could be solved with some awesome technique he came up with
then he died before writing it down properly
heh
it's ok, I have it specced already
No, in the margin of some other spec.
s/spec/book/
and it became a huge challenge for other people to prove, they managed recently but it was brutally hard (and not his solution)
well, minor a few technical details about the algorithm. But the concept is sound
You're confusing me
He wrote it in 1637, proved in 1995.
Fermat had proof when he wrote it, just never written down.
*thought he had a proof
I think the general consensus is that he was wrong
Well, yeah.
rather than that he was cleverer than four centuries of mathematicians
I checked in the new and improved solution for selectors api. http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/selectors-api2/
the major changes have to do with the definition of "scoped selector string" and the ways in which that affects processing.
how can something be both new and improved?
Steve^, it's a new technique that is an improvement over the old technique
that's what you meant, yes

/me wonders if/why "

Y" should parse differently to "

X

Y"
hsivonen: ^
It seems to me that the active formatting elements should be reconstructed on either the space or the X but there are tests that suggest it doesn't happen with the space
i think that changed at some point
OK, I couldn't obviously see a relevant commit message
if you have the time, try archeology for the line "A character token" a the top of the in-body insertion mode
jgraham: is my code out of date on that point?
hsivonen: Well the HTML5 live DOM viewer disagrees with html5lib but agrees with the tests
But I *think* html5lib agrees with the spec
I see
Unless there is a special case I am missing somewhere
(which is quite likely)
I thought I'd written code that makes both space and other characters follow the same path in "in body"
hsivonen: You have any thoughts about how to make the tokenizer tests JSON, like the docs claim?
hsivonen: Is the HTML5 live dom viewer up to date at this point?
gsnedders: do you mean surrogates?
hsivonen: I was thinking adding in a second form of escaping above JSON, so you can do things like U00D7FF to refer to U+D7FF (which can't occur in JSON)
jgraham: it's not up to spec
jgraham: at least has changed
hsivonen: Is it significantly older than the version in gecko?
jgraham: and end tags before <html>
jgraham: no
hsivonen: Yes, and anything else that can't be represented
the only change that's in Gecko but not in the Live viewer is that Gecko no longer clones nodes
What makes \uD7FF illegal in JSON?
(that fix was long overdue)
gsnedders: no, I don't know what to do about that
did JSON fall into the same trap as XML and outlaw characters according to someone's sense of Unicode aesthetics?
optimistically changes the tests locally
JSON didn't, but to make it a subset of ECMAScript it has to be.
We can't run the html5lib tests on Ruby at all because of it
With that change we are down to 2 errors, 2 failures
gsnedders: :-(
having to create another escaping layer on top of JSON would suck
The ruby port is somewhat dead in the water
I see no alternative though :(
jgraham: I want to do some stuff with it in the near future
(but this problem really needs to be fixed)
gsnedders: Good luck with that
But yeah, I really want to get the tests running before I do anything
